The epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) is a cell surface receptor that is activated by the binding of ligands such as epidermal growth factor (EGF). The EGFR is frequently over-expressed in human cancers and its expression is often associated with a more aggressive tumor phenotype and a poorer prognosis. The EGFR is a member of a family of closely related tyrosine kinase receptors that also include the neu / HER2, HER3 and HER4 receptors. Binding of ligand to the EGFR leads to receptor dimerization and activation of downstream signaling pathways, including the ras-raf-MEK-MAPK and PI3K-Akt pathways. These pathways ultimately result in cellular proliferation, inhibition of apoptosis and enhanced cell motility and metastasis.

The cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA) is a serine / threonine kinase that is activated by the second messenger cAMP. In mammals, there are two genes that encode the regulatory subunits of PKA, RIalpha and RIIalpha. The two PKA regulatory subunits are highly similar in sequence and structure, and are expressed in different tissues. The RIIalpha regulatory subunit is highly expressed in brain, while the RIalpha regulatory subunit is expressed in most tissues. The PKA catalytic subunit is encoded by a single gene that is expressed as two isoforms, Cα and PKCIbeta, that are expressed in different tissues. The PKA holoenzyme is a tetramer consisting of a dimer of regulatory subunits and two dimers of catalytic subunits. The regulatory subunits are encoded by two genes, PRKACA and PRKACB. The PKA holoenzyme is inactive in the absence of cAMP and is activated by the binding of cAMP to the regulatory subunits, releasing the catalytic subunits to phosphorylate downstream targets. The release of the catalytic subunits is transient and the regulatory subunits deactivate and re-bind to cAMP to reform the inactive PKA holoenzyme. The PKA regulatory subunits are encoded by two genes, PRKACB and PRKACG. The PKA catalytic subunits are encoded by a single gene, PRKACA. The PKA catalytic subunits are encoded by two genes, PRKACA1 and PRKACA2. The PKA regulatory and catalytic subunits are expressed differently in different tissues.

Parkinson's disease (PD) is a common neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the selective loss of dopaminergic (DA) neurons in the substantia nigra (SN). Although the etiology of PD is still unknown, genetic studies have identified several causative genes, including alpha-synuclein, parkin, PTEN induced kinase 1 (PINK1), and DJ-1. These genes are involved in diverse cellular functions, such as mitochondrial quality control, oxidative stress response, and protein handling. Emerging evidence suggests that mitochondrial dysfunction plays a central role in the pathogenesis of PD. Mitochondria are dynamic organelles that constantly fuse and divide to adapt to their environment. The mitochondrial fusion process is mediated by mitofusins (Mfn1 and Mfn2) and optic atrophy 1 (OPA1), whereas the mitochondrial fission process is mediated by Drp1 and Fis1. The proper maintenance of mitochondrial homeostasis is essential for cell survival. However, when mitochondria are damaged, they are eliminated by a process known as mitophagy. Parkin, PINK1, and the ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS) are involved in this process. In normal conditions, Parkin is recruited from the cytosol to depolarized mitochondria in a PINK1-dependent manner. Parkin subsequently mediates ubiquitination of mitochondrial proteins, which in turn leads to their degradation by the UPS. The UPS is impaired in PD patients with parkin mutations, which may result in the accumulation of damaged mitochondria and the subsequent DA neuronal death.

The mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway is a highly conserved signaling module involved in the transduction of extracellular signals to intracellular targets. The pathway is comprised of a three-tiered kinase cascade, with Raf being the MAPKKK at the top of the cascade. The MAPKKK phosphorylates and activates the MAPKKs, which in turn phosphorylate and activate the MAPKs. The MAPKs are a family of kinases involved in a variety of cellular processes including proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis. The MAPKs are classified into three groups based on their structure and function: extracellular signal-regulated kinases (ERKs), Jun amino-terminal kinases (JNKs), and p3 8 kinases. The Raf-1 kinase is the MAPKKK in the ERK pathway, and is activated by the small G-protein Ras. The MAPKKs include MEK1 and MEK2, which activate ERK1 and ERK2, and MKK3 and MKK6, which activate the JNK and p3 8 kinases. The MKK3 and MKK6 kinases are activated by the MAPKKK ASK1, which is activated by the transforming MAPKKK, Tpl-2. The JNKs are activated by the MAPKKK MEKK1, and the MAPKK SEK1, which is activated by the MAPKKK ASK1. The ERK5 kinase is activated by MEK5, which is activated by the MAPKKK MEK4. The ERK5 kinase is involved in the regulation of cell proliferation and survival. Crosstalk occurs between the different MAPK pathways, and the activation of one pathway can inhibit the other. For example, activation of the JNK pathway can inhibit the ERK pathway by blocking the activation of Raf1.

Glutamate is the major excitatory neurotransmitter in the mammalian central nervous system (CNS). Glutamate acts at ionotropic (AMPA, NMDA, and kainate) and metabotropic (mGlu1-8) receptors. At the ionotropic glutamate receptors, glutamate binds to ligand-gated ion channels (iGluRs), which are tetramers of GluR1-4 subunits. NMDA receptors are cation channels that are activated by glutamate and blocked by Mg2 + ions. The binding of glutamate to the NMDA receptor relieves the Mg2 + block, allowing Ca2 + influx. The glutamate-induced influx of Ca2 + into the cell triggers a variety of cellular responses, including the activation of protein kinases and phospholipases. At metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs), glutamate acts on G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs). mGluRs are divided into three groups on the basis of their sequence homology, pharmacological properties, and effector coupling. Group I mGluRs (mGluR1 and 5) are coupled to Gq / 1 1 proteins and activate phospholipase C (PLC). Group II mGluRs (mGluR2 and 3) and group III mGluRs (mGluR4, 6, 7, and 8) are negatively coupled to cAMP formation through Gi / o proteins. The activation of PLC results in IP3 production, which stimulates release of Ca2 + from intracellular stores and activates protein kinase C (PKC). In addition, activation of Gq / 1 1 leads to the activation of the small G protein Rho and its effector kinase, Rho-associated coiled-coil-containing protein kinase (ROCK). Rho and ROCK subsequently activate a kinase cascade involving the phosphorylation of myosin light chain (MLC) and subsequent stimulation of the formation of contractile actin-myosin filaments. The activation of PKC also contributes to the regulation of MLC phosphorylation through the inhibition of myosin phosphatase (MP). The activation of mGluRs also leads to the stimulation of mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPKs), including the extracellular signal-regulated kinases (ERKs), Jun N-terminal kinases (JNKs), and p38 MAPKs. The activation of these kinases contributes to the regulation of gene expression and other cellular responses.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a genetically and clinically heterogeneous disease. Molecular analysis has identified several distinct groups of AML based on their genetic abnormalities. These groups include those with translocations involving RUNX1 (also known as AML1), such as t (8; 2 1) (AML-M2), t (1 5; 1 7) (AML-M3), and inv (AML-M4Eo), those with mutations in NPM1 (AML-M4eo), those with mutations in C / EBPα (AML-M3v), and those with abnormalities of KIT (AML-mast). These molecular abnormalities affect various cellular functions, such as transcription, cell differentiation, signaling, and apoptosis.

The heat shock protein Hsp70 (Hsp7 0) is a molecular chaperone that is induced by a variety of cellular stresses, including heat, heavy metals, and oxidative stress. Hsp70 has been shown to inhibit apoptosis induced by a variety of stimuli, including Fas, TNF-alpha, and heat. The anti-apoptotic activity of Hsp70 is dependent on the ability of Hsp70 to bind to and stabilize the pro-apoptotic protein Bax. In addition, Hsp70 can inhibit apoptosis by blocking the Apaf-1-mediated caspase-9 activation pathway. The ability of Hsp70 to inhibit apoptosis is dependent on its phosphorylation state. When Hsp70 is phosphorylated, it inhibits apoptosis, but dephosphorylation of Hsp70 allows apoptosis to proceed. The phosphorylation of Hsp70 is regulated by the stress-activated protein kinase (SAPK) / Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) and the protein kinase AKT. The phosphorylation of Hsp70 by the SAPK / JNK pathway is stimulated by TNF and inhibits apoptosis, while the phosphorylation of Hsp70 by AKT inhibits apoptosis and is stimulated by growth factors. The inhibition of apoptosis by Hsp70 is also dependent on the presence of the co-chaperone AIF (apoptosis inducing factor). AIF is a mitochondrial protein that translocates to the nucleus to induce chromatin condensation and large-scale DNA fragmentation in a caspase-independent manner. Hsp70 binds to AIF and prevents it from entering the nucleus. The inhibition of apoptosis by Hsp70 is also dependent on the presence of the co-chaperone p40 0. Hsp70 and p40 0 form a complex that binds to AIF and prevents it from entering the nucleus. The ability of Hsp70 to inhibit apoptosis is dependent on the presence of Hsp70 in the mitochondria. In the absence of Hsp70, AIF is released from the mitochondria and induces apoptosis.

Leukocyte trafficking from the bloodstream into tissues is a key component of the inflammatory response. During inflammation, endothelial cells in the walls of blood vessels express chemokines that attract leukocytes to the site of inflammation. The first step in the recruitment of leukocytes into inflamed tissues is their tethering and rolling on the vascular endothelium. This is mediated by the interaction of selectins on the leukocyte surface with their ligands on the endothelial cells. The rolling step is followed by activation of integrins on the leukocyte surface, which bind their ligands on the endothelial cells. The leukocytes then firmly adhere to the endothelium and extravasate into the inflamed tissue. The rolling and adhesion of leukocytes is a dynamic process, with the leukocytes constantly undergoing rolling along the endothelial cells, and the rolling velocity is determined by the strength of the interaction between the selectins and their ligands. The interaction of selectins with their ligands is regulated by the addition and removal of carbohydrates from the ligands by glycosyltransferases and glycosidases. The addition of carbohydrates to selectin ligands is catalyzed by the enzyme O-GlcNAc transferase (OGT). The removal of carbohydrates is catalyzed by the enzyme O-GlcNAcase (OGA). Inhibition of OGT or activation of OGA blocks selectin-mediated rolling and leukocyte trafficking. Inhibition of OGT also blocks the recruitment of leukocytes into inflamed tissues in vivo. The addition of carbohydrates to selectin ligands is a dynamic process, and is regulated by the expression of the glycosyltransferases and glycosidases that modify the selectin ligands. The addition of carbohydrates by OGT is reversible, and the removal of carbohydrates by OGA is also a reversible process. The addition of carbohydrates by OGT is required for selectin ligand activity, and the removal of carbohydrates by OGA is required for selectin ligand inactivation. The addition and removal of carbohydrates by OGT and OGA is a dynamic process that regulates the activity of selectin ligands and thus the rolling and adhesion of leukocytes.

Transcription of rRNA genes by RNA polymerase I is the rate-limiting step in ribosome biogenesis and accounts for up to 6 0% of all nuclear transcription. RNA polymerase I is a multi-subunit enzyme consisting of 1 4 subunits, and its activity is regulated by a number of factors. The transcription factor UBF binds to the core promoter and upstream control region of the rRNA genes and recruits the SL1 complex to the promoter. The SL1 complex is formed by TATA-binding protein (TBP) and TBP-associated factors (TAFs). The activity of UBF is regulated by phosphorylation and acetylation. Cyclin dependent kinase (CDK) -cyclin complexes phosphorylate UBF at CDK consensus sites, and this increases the affinity of UBF for the rRNA promoter. The histone acetylase PCAF interacts with UBF and stimulates its activity. The tumor suppressor p53 interacts with PCAF and inhibits its histone acetylase activity, thus repressing rRNA transcription. The tumor suppressor RB interacts with PCAF and represses rRNA transcription by blocking the interaction of PCAF with UBF. The T-box transcription factor TBX2 represses rRNA transcription by interacting with PCAF and blocking its histone acetylase activity. The Myb transcription factor c-Myb activates the expression of genes involved in the cell cycle and stimulates rRNA transcription. The interaction of c-Myb with PCAF is blocked by the coactivator CBP, which represses rRNA transcription. The interaction of c-Myb with PCAF is also blocked by p53, which represses rRNA transcription. The interaction of T-box transcription factor 2 (TBX2) with PCAF represses rRNA transcription. The interaction of Twist with PCAF represses rRNA transcription. Twist is a basic helix-lop helix transcription factor that plays an important role in development.

The FA pathway is required for the repair of DNA damage induced by crosslinking agents such as cisplatin and mitomycin C. Cells from patients with a defective FA pathway are extremely sensitive to crosslinking agents and are genetically unstable. The FA proteins cooperate in a common pathway that includes at least eight complementation groups (A, B, C, E, F, G and L). In the pathway, the FA-A protein binds to the FA-B, -C, -E, -F, and -G proteins to form a nuclear complex. The complex is required for the ubiquitination of the FANCD2 protein by the FA-C, -E, -F, and -G proteins in response to DNA damage. The ubiquitinated FANCD2 protein associates with BRCA2 and other proteins in chromatin to form nuclear foci that are thought to be involved in DNA repair. The checkpoint kinase ATR is also required for the ubiquitination of FANCD2 in response to DNA damage, but does not appear to be required for the formation of the nuclear foci. The checkpoint kinase ATM is also required for the ubiquitination of FANCD2 in response to DNA damage, but is not required for the formation of the nuclear foci. The checkpoint kinase ATR is also required for the ubiquitination of FANCD2 in response to DNA damage, but does not appear to be required for the formation of the nuclear foci. The checkpoint kinase ATM is also required for the ubiquitination of FANCD2 in response to DNA damage, but is not required for the formation of the nuclear foci. The checkpoint clamp complex RAD1 7-RAD4-ATAD5 is also required for the ubiquitination of FANCD2 in response to DNA damage, but does not appear to be required for the formation of the nuclear foci. The RAD1 7-RAD4-ATAD5 complex loads the 9-1-1 complex at sites of DNA damage to signal the presence of DNA damage. The checkpoint clamp loader RAD1 7-RAD4-ATAD5 complex may recruit the FA complex to the site of DNA damage, where the FA complex activates the ubiquitination of FANCD2 by the E3 ubiquitin ligase complex consisting of the FANCL, B, C, E, and G proteins. The ubiquitinated FANCD2 protein associates with BRCA2 and other proteins in chromatin to form nuclear foci that are involved in DNA repair. The removal of the ubiquitin groups from FANCD2 by the deubiquitinating enzyme UAF1 / USP2L3 may be required for the release of the repaired DNA from the repair complex.

Chondroitin sulfate is a sulfated polysaccharide of glucuronic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine. Chondroitin sulfate chains are attached to core proteins to form proteoglycans. The biosynthesis of chondroitin sulfate starts with the transfer of N-acetylgalactosamine-glucuronic acid disaccharide repeat unit to a serine residue of a core protein by the enzyme, chondroitin synthase. After the assembly of the disaccharide repeat unit, various modifications occur. The first modification is the addition of a sulfate group to position 6 of the N-acetylgalactosamine. This modification is catalyzed by the enzyme, chondroitin-6-sulfotransferase. The second modification is the addition of a sulfate group to position 4 of the glucuronic acid. This modification is catalyzed by the enzyme, chondroitin sulfate N-acetylgalactosaminyltransferase. The third modification is the epimerization of glucuronic acid to iduronic acid. This modification is catalyzed by the enzyme, uronyl 2-sulfotransferase. Chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans are found in a number of tissues, including cartilage, brain, and the eye. Chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans are involved in a variety of biological processes, including cell adhesion, cell-cell communication, and embryonic development.

Apoptosis or programmed cell death plays an important role in the development and homeostasis of multicellular organisms. Defects in the regulation of apoptosis can lead to the development of various diseases, including cancer. The execution of apoptosis is carried out by a family of proteases known as caspases. The activation of caspases results in the cleavage of a number of cellular proteins that are important for maintaining cellular structure and function. In this section, we will discuss the different pathways that activate caspases and the role of caspases in apoptosis.
